title-group.article-title: A study exploring regional level predictors of suicide rates across time in Sweden

article-meta.aff: 1National Centre for Suicide Research and Prevention (NASP), Karolinska Institute, Solna, Stockholm, Sweden
article-meta.issue-title: Abstracts of the 32nd European Congress of Psychiatry

license.license-p: This is an Open Access article, distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution licence (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/), which permits unrestricted re-use, distribution, and reproduction in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In Sweden, four lives are lost to suicide each day. Hence, identifying relevant risk factors to inform effective prevention strategies is key. Such strategies can range from individual (‘micro’) -level prevention methods, to broader national suicide prevention policies.

sec.title: Objectives
sec.p: Whilst a range of studies have explored individual-level risk factors, highlighting municipal, regional, or national-level predictors can be valuable to identify broader social and contextual determinants. This study will therefore aim to go beyond proximal predictors of suicide by looking through a wider national- and regional-level lens in Sweden.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: This project will be conducted utilizing routinely collected and publicly available data and applying longitudinal modelling to investigate potential predictors of changes in suicide rates across time in Sweden. More specifically, the study will explore whether regional data on economic (e.g. proportion of state benefit recipients), socio-demographic (e.g. educational level) and healthcare related variables (e.g. trust in the healthcare system) are associated with suicide rates over time.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: This is an ongoing project and results will be available and presented at the time of the conference.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Utilizing publicly available data to explore potential predictors of suicide rates is not only cost-effective, but adding such findings to existing knowledge of individual-level risk factors can also be important when targeting wider policy and ensuring effective coordination and implementation of regional suicide prevention strategies.
